docs.snippet: A large number of the friends of Marshal RINDERS very quietly arranged to give him a serenade last night, at his residence, No. 52 Henry-street. It was intended principally as a friendly visit, and partly to congratulate him upon his confirmation.

headline.main: SERENADE TO MARSHAL RYNDERS.; The Marshal's Opinion of Serenades, and of the Sycophants who Generally get them up.

docs.lead_paragraph: A large number of the friends of Marshal RINDERS very quietly arranged to give him a serenade last night, at his residence, No. 52 Henry-street. It was intended principally as a friendly visit, and partly to congratulate him upon his confirmation.

headline.main: WASHINGTON GOSSIP.; The Exodus from the Metropolis--Close of the Fashionable Season--Last Reception at the White House--Flight of the Diplomats and the Cabinet--Captain Meigs in Trouble--New Senate Hall--Old Hall of the House--Masonic--Operatic and Theatrical-Excursions--Summer Solstice--An Revoir.

docs.lead_paragraph: " Our own" political correspondents hete have announced the demise of the first session of the Thirty fifth Congress on the 14th inst., and have duly chronic ed the calm resignation and decorous submlssion to Executive will which characterized its last moment. The signal flags which show that the Houses beneath them are in session had not been pulled down ere the members began to leave, and there has ever since been a general excdus.

headline.main: Fuss Over Small Matters--Neglect of Large Ones.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your issue of the 19th instant contains some strictures, signed " Civis," on a disconnected paragraph in my letter on the above subject, in the NEWYORK TIMES of the 16th. According to " Civis," the cry of the newsboy on Sunday is as " serious a trifle " as filthy streets and encumbered sidewalks. He does not continue the

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; The Yacht Race. EXPLANATION. Police Intelligence. Mayor's Office. Coroner's Inquest.

docs.snippet: To the Editor of the New-York Times: I cannot forbear stating a startling incident of the storm of last evening. A few yards from my dwelling a child was returning from school in the height of the tempest.
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: I cannot forbear stating a startling incident of the storm of last evening. A few yards from my dwelling a child was returning from school in the height of the tempest.

headline.main: KANSAS AFFAIRS.; Evidence for the Prosecution Concerning the Murder of Mr. Jenkias. Trial of General Lane for Murder.

docs.abstract: Tried for the murder of Jenkins
docs.lead_paragraph: The trail of General J. H. LANE for the murder of Mr. GAINS JENKINS commenced to-day before Justice LADD, assisted by Justices SOULE and OTTERSON. The counsel for the prosecution are Messrs. SAPFORD, (Country-Attorney,) COE, LAWMAN, WOOD, COLLAMORE AND STANTON; for defendant, Messrs. YOUNG, T. EWING. HUTCHINSON, CHRISTIAN and H. EWING.

headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM UTAH.; Gov. Cumming's Visit to Salt Lake--Col. Kane's Operations--Army Movements--Mormon Outrages--The Peace Commissioners. Arrival of 150 Emigrant Mormons from Salt Lake City at Camp Scott. A Fortnight Later from Salt Lake City. Interesting Accounts from Camp Scott. Gov. Cumming Watched by Spies and Denounced by Brigham Young. Important Intelligence of the Designs of the Mormons.

headline.main: AFFAIRS IN VIRGINIA.; Trial of a Catholic Priest for Murder--The Next Governership of Virginia--John Letcher--He Successor in Congress--The Next Presidency--Governor Wise in the Field.

docs.lead_paragraph: The trial of a Catholic priest, the Rev. DANIEL DOWNEY, for the murder of a man named MULLINS, has just been concluded in the Superior Court of this town, having occupied nine days and a half. It resulted in a disagreement of the Jury--nine being for a verdict of murder in the second degree and three for acquittal.

docs.snippet: THE POLICE PARADE.--The following ronte has been agreed upon for the Police parade to-day. At 121/2 e'clock the New-York policemen form in line in front of the Police Head-quarters in Broome-street. thence march down Broaw way to the Park, where at 2...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE POLICE PARADE.--The following ronte has been agreed upon for the Police parade to-day. At 121/2 e'clock the New-York policemen form in line in front of the Police Head-quarters in Broome-street. thence march down Broaw way to the Park, where at 2 P. M. they will be reviewed in forat of the City Hall, by Gov. KING, the Mayor, and Common Council.

headline.main: AFFAIRS IN FRANCE.; The weather-Rumors About the Emperor--Court Amusements--A Matter of Ribbons The Pebe Affair--More Duels.
